characters: J U L I E T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ribbon of freeway stretching into a blue and pink late afternoon sky. A huge dark sedan, windows tinted gold, headlights blazing, powers directly for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: A heavy, low-slung, pickup truck traveling toward the sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT: Sky, freeway, the cars closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON: The sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON: The pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like thunderous, jousting opponents, the cars pass in a deafening cacophony of noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON: The fat face of GREGORY, yelling at the disappearing sedan.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: A dog of the house of Capulet moves me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and the pimply-faced front-seat passenger, SAMPSON, explode with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red-haired driver BENVOLIO, keeps his eyes on the roa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck spirals down an exit ramp and screeches into bu driveway of a large gas station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attendants immediately run to the truck. Two clean windshields and duco, the third fills the gas tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory in the back seat is boasting outrageously.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: A dog of that house shall move me to stand. I will take the wall of any man or maid of Capulets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson, sarcastically.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: That shows thee a weak slave. For the weakest goes to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: 'Tis true; and therefore women, being the weaker vessels, are ever thrust to the wall. Therefore, I will push Capulet's men from the wall, and thrust his maids to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio, disgusted, gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: The quarrel is between our masters...

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (yelling after him) ...and us their men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW: Benvolio as he heads for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PICK UP: A mother wrangling three little boys out of a station wagon - the smallest kid carries a toy pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER FAST SCAN TRACK: Past the mother to - the huge blac sedan pulling up outside the gas station mini-mart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door of the sedan opens. Shiny black boots - decorated with tiny, silver, cat-shaped spurs - plant themselves on the ground. The boots are joined by two oth pairs of well-shod feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD: The spurred boots move out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE UP: The other feet belong to a tough-looking Latin youth ABRA - and his goateed side-kick PETRUCHIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abra and Petruchio enter the mini-mart, as four white-cla girls exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW: The girls as they head for their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER FAST SCAN TRACK: Past the girls to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson is trying to out boast Gregory.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: I will show myself a tyrant. When I have fought with the men I will be civil with the maids, I will cut off their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory; mock outrage.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: The heads of the maids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson leers lecherously at the girls.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maiden heads, take it in what sense thou wilt.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: They must take it in sense that feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory and Sampson pump up the song on the sound system sing out at the girls.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY/SAMPSON
dialogues.text: (SINGING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a pretty piece of flesh! I am a pretty piece of flesh! Me, they shall feel while I am able to stand; I am a pretty piece of flesh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls, pretending not to notice, get into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GREGORY'S P.O.V.: The car pulls away revealing... Abra an Petruchio exiting the mini-mart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Gregory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Sampson - Their singing abruptly halts.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: Here comes of the House of Capulet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abra and Petruchio stare coldly toward the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Sampson swallowing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Gregory; eyes locked to the Capulets. With fake bravado he nudges Sampson.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Quarrel I will back thee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Sampson trying to quell his rising panic.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: Let us take the law of our sides. Let them begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY: BANG! Gregory and Sampson jump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHIP PAN: It was the garage attendant slamming the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory and Sampson are mortally embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abra and Petruchio laugh contemptuously and move to their

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW: The mother and kids exiting the mini-mart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER FAST SCAN TRACK: To...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson furiously tries to save face.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: I will bite my thumb at them; which is a disgrace to them if they bear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson quickly bites his thumb toward Abra's back as he gets into the sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abra's eyes flick to the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E.C.U.: The rear view mirror; Sampson biting his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, a blood curdling screech of tires - the sedan, rubber burning, reverses full speed toward Sampson and Gregory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mother in the station wagon brakes to avoid collision a sports car shunts into her vehicle. Mother and children scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attendants scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Capulet car shudders to a halt inches from the truck, blocking its path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A scurry of limbs scrabbling across seats and reaching for door handles;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abra hauls Sampson from the truck. Gregory leaps out, Petruchio covers him. Abra slams Sampson against the side the vehicle - then, goading him to go for his gun, scream

dialogues.speaker: ABRA
dialogues.text: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sampson's shaking hand hovers - ready to draw.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: I do bite my thumb, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The panicked mother in the station wagon. She motions her children to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Customers run for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Abra: An hysterical rage; he shrieks:

dialogues.speaker: ABRA
dialogues.text: Do you bite you thumb at us, sir?

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: (sweating, murmurs to Gregory) Is the law on our side if I say "Ay"?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The black cowboy boots, trousers down around th The sound of a toilet flushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN TO: The next cubicle, the door opens revealing Benvol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Sampson, still sweating.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir - but I do bite my thumb, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Gregory; a ridiculous inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Do you quarrel, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Abra; a dangerous smile.

dialogues.speaker: ABRA
dialogues.text: Quarrel sir, no sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Sampson; unconvincing bravado...

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: But if you do, sir, I am for you. I serve as good a man as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Abra; a lethal question.

dialogues.speaker: ABRA
dialogues.text: No better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Sampson, trapped.

dialogues.speaker: SAMPSON
dialogues.text: Well sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Inside the station wagon. The mother does not notice her five year old aiming a toy gun toward the boys

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Gregory's P.O.V.: Benvolio emerging from the bathroom - he whispers maniacally.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Here comes our kinsman. Say better!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP: Sampson; he screams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP: Abra demonically roars:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Benvolio. Terror stricken, he sees the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISTORTED OUT OF CONTROL CLOSE UP: Abra shrieks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIGHTNING CUT: Four hands reaching for guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAM ZOOM: To Benvolio - weapon outstretched he screams:

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Part, fools! You know not what you do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC STING; A SUPER MARCO SLAM ZOOM along the barrel of Benvolio's gun; the engraved gun type reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Sword 9mm series S'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Benvolio. He screams in desperation:

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Put up your swords!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory, Sampson, Abra, and Petruchio freeze. A moment - then from behind, the unmistakable sound of a gun being cocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP: The black cowboy boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE UP: To find the dark cold eyes and feline smile, of the wearer of the boots. His name is TYBALT; a cigarette clenched between his teeth and his gun is aimed at Benvol head.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: What, art thou drawn amoung these heartless hinds? Turn thee Benvolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio, a choked explanation:

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: I do but keep the peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mocking smile.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Peace? I hate the word As I hate hell, all Montagues, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP: Tybalt's finger squeezing the trigger..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we hear firing from Tybalt's blind side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt redirects his weapon, cracking off a single shot a the surprise attacker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the five year old from the station wagon. The bulle smacks the toy gun from the child's hand, shattering the wagon's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother and children scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panicked Benvolio falls back, accidentally his gun fire the bullet whistles past Tybalt's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt combat rolls, and using a screaming car load of gi as cover, returns two quick shots, narrowly missing Benvo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas station attendant hits a button and heavy metal screens slam down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Gregory firing - a bullet rips through Abra's arm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petruchio dives for cover; Gregory and Sampson leap into Benvolio's truck. Rubber burns as they smash past the Capulet vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Tybalt taking aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His first shot plugs the fuel tank, the second a tire. Ou of control and spewing gasoline the Montague truck careen across the highway and through the glass front of a supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory and Sampson throw themselves from the truck momen before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The gas tank erupts into an almighty fireball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen fills with flame: the following images combust front of us:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEWS CHOPPER P.O.V.: Citizens run in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looters raid shops near the supermarket - security guards return fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A table of dark suited men and their wives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The powerful 60 year old face of FULGENCIO CAPU Seated next to him is his much younger wife GLORIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY: Windows explode in a tidal wave of glass. Diner take cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet moves fearlessly toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: (to a waiter) Give me my long sword!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The word MONTAGUE fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: We see the word is the number plate of a large black limousine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine is stuck in the traffic snarl - bullets bou off its bullet proof windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TED MONTAGUE, a 60 year old red-faced bulldog of a man, bursts from the back of the limousine.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: What noise is this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted draws an enormous pearl handed revolver, CAROLINE, his conservatively dressed wife, tries to restrain him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe!

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: (shrugging her off) Hold me not, let me go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crouched behind a truck, Benvolio shakily tries to re-loa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The barrel of Tybalt's gun enters frame and presses into Benvolio's forehead. Tybalt whispers sweetly

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Look upon thy death, Benvolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Tybalt's finger on the trigger. Benvolio scream a scream of mortal horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY Tybalt is blinded by a burning shaft of light. A magnificently powerful helicopter gunship hovers above hi A command booms from the chopper's public address system.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: (over PA) Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace, Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The steely gray eyes of CAPTAIN PRINCE, chief o the Verona Beach Police Department. He lifts the micropho and repeats the command.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt looks up to the chopper. Patrol cars screech to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An almighty orchestral chord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER WIDE SHOT: A trail of devastation winds up through grid-locked traffic to the burning supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance looms an enormous statue of Christ flanke by two glass towers. We push toward the towers. One is neon-crowned MONTAGUE, the other, CAPULET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Two households, both alike in dignity. In fair Verona, where we lay our

dialogues.speaker: SCENE
dialogues.text: From ancient grudge break to new mutiny, Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean. From forth the fatal loins of these two foes A pair of star crossed lovers take their life. Whose misadventured piteous

dialogues.speaker: OVERTHROWS
dialogues.text: Doth with their death bury their parents strife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark chord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swarm of helicopters thunder into frame. We see compressed, time-lapsed, images of their journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAM INTO: A coat of arms that labels a large tower - the emblem reads; "Verona Beach Police Department: In God We Trust".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Captain Prince's grim features. He eyes Capulet and Montague.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: Three civil brawls, bred of an airy

dialogues.speaker: WORD
dialogues.text: By thee, old Capulet, and Montague, Have thrice disturbed the quiet of our streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet's lawyer tries to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: My noble Prince I can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Prince overriding, slams the desk.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: If ever you disturb our streets again, Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on Captain Prince's determined gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A majestic sunrise; Ted Montague's limousine sulks throug deserted streets. In the distance, Jesus looks out over t now peaceful city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Montague, his wife Caroline, and nephew Benvolio ride uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline finally speaks her anger.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: O where is Romeo? Saw you him today? (pointedly to Montague) Right glad I am he was not at this fray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montague snorts derisively and stares out the window. Embarrassed, Benvolio tries to be of assistance.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Madam, underneath The Grove of

dialogues.speaker: SYCAMORE
dialogues.text: So early walking did I see your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Montague speaks with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: Many a morning hath he there been

dialogues.speaker: SEEN
dialogues.text: With tears augmenting the fresh morning's dew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline struggles to contain her emotion.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Away from light steals home my heavy son And private in his chamber pens himself, Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out And makes himself an artificial night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montague barks into the car intercom.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: Westward from this city side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine U-turns heading west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the melancholic strains of Mozart's "Serenade for Wind we see a blond nineteen year old boy sitting alone on an empty beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The boy, ROMEO. Looking out over the ocean he sucks on the last of a cigarette and then writes intensel in a small worn note book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear his voice over.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Love is a smoke made with the fume of sighs; Being purged, a fire sparkling in lovers' eyes; Being vexed, a sea nourished with lovers' tears. What is it else? A madness most discreet, A choking gall and a preserving sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo is parked in a cross street that runs down to th beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opposite the limo, young diehard clubbers, faded drag que and street people, hang outside a dilapidated nightclub. broken neon sign reads: "The Grove of Sick Amore."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, Caroline and Benvolio sit watching the silhouette of Romeo on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: Black and portentous must this humour prove Unless good counsel may the cause remove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V.: From the limousine. Romeo rises and listlessly makes his way up the beach - seeing his father's car he turns and heads for the path that hugs the beach front.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: So please you step aside. I'll know his grievance or be much denied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio clambers out of the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Montague, an encouraging smile.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: Come Madam. Let's away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine pulls away and Benvolio heads after Romeo. pauses. A deck at the rear of "Sick Amore" sprawls onto t beach. At the base of the deck, Benvolio can see Romeo squatting in discussion with an old drunk. Benvolio approaches with a not very convincing casualness.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Good morrow, cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo turns. Sore, red, unfriendly eyes squint back at Benvolio.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Is the day so young?

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: But new struck, Coz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo rises, Benvolio follows.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Ay me! Sad hours seem long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo stops as if taking in Benvolio for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Was that my father that went hence so fast?

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: (GUILTY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio chases Romeo down the path which divides the bea from a string of cheap souvenir shops and sleazy bars.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Not having that which having makes them short.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: In love?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Of love?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Out of her favor where I am in love.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Alas that love, so gentle in his view, Should be so tyrannical and rough in proof!

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Alas that love, whose view...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo is halted by the sight of last night's disturbance displayed on a small TV screen in an outdoor bar.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What fray was here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio starts to reply.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (ANGRILY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet tell me not, for I have heard it all. Here's much to do with hate, but more with love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo turns the corner away from the beach. He strides along the sidewalk raging.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Why then, O brawling love, O loving hate, O anything, of nothing first create! O heavy lightness, serious vanity, Misshapen chaos of well-seeming forms, Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health, Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo screams at a huge bouncer who lounges in the doorwa of a sex club.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: This love feel I, that feel no love in this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bouncer's hand moves to his gun. Romeo, ignoring him, turns on Benvolio. A mocking laughter through tears:

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Dost thou not laugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio, nervously eyeing the bouncer, shepherds Romeo o of danger.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: No, coz, I rather weep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Farewell, my coz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, breaking into a jog, leaves Benvolio behind. Benvo pursues him down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The sleeping face of a fourteen year old boy - BALTHASAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: Balthasar sleeps on the hood of a magnificent silver car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three or four kids doze on the sidewalk. As Romeo approaches, they jump up and begin vigorously polishing t already gleaming car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balthasar wakes. He springs off the hood, chases the kids away, then, producing a huge bunch of keys, opens the car door for Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio intercepts Romeo at the car.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Tell me in sadness, who is it that you love.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: In sadness, cousin, I do love...a woman.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: I aimed so near when I supposed you loved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo leans against the car.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: A right good marksman; and she's fair I love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo pulls his shirt down to reveal a small shoulder tat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The tattooed word; ROSALINE.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Rosaline! (he is impressed) A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: She'll not be hit with Cupid's arrow. She hath Dian's wit, And in strong proof of chastity lives well armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Then she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: She hath; and in that sparing makes huge waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio - a plan.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Be ruled by me; forget to think of her.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: O, teach me how I should forget to think!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio indicates one of the working girls already strut the foot path.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: By giving liberty unto thine eyes. Examine other beauties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo laughs dismissively. He throws the kids a few coins and slides into the drivers seat. Balthasar jumps in back

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Farewell. Thou canst not teach me to forget.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: I'll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio leaps into the passenger seat of the moving vehi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orchestral fanfare. TRACK DOWN: Past monstrous letters that read CAPULET and in through a window to discover Fulgencio Capulet. He stares out the window toward the other tallest building in Verona; the one crested with th word MONTAGUE.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: But Montague is bound as well as I, In penalty alike;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet turns: on the other side of his desk sits DAVID PARIS; a square-jawed young man in a red cashmere sweater Tea has been served from an exquisite silver tea service.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And 'tis not hard, I think, for me so old as we to keep the peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave smiles obligingly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Of honorable reckoning are you both, And pity 'tis you lived at odds so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward pause: Dave sips tea, then, with a deep breath

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet considers the framed photograph on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: But saying o'er what I have said BEFORE; My child is yet a stranger in the WORLD; Let two more summers wither in their pride, Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave is politely insistent.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Younger than she are happy mothers made.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: (checking him hard) And too soon marred are those so early made. Earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she; She is the hopeful lady of my earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet rounds the desk and places a fatherly hand on Dav shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart. My will to her consent is but a part, And she agreed, within her scope of

dialogues.speaker: CHOICE
dialogues.text: Lies my consent and fair according voice. This night I hold an old Accustomed feast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet leans close.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: At my poor house, look to behold this night, Fresh female buds that make dark heaven light. Hear all; all see, And like her most whose merit most shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet smiles knowingly. Dave seems encouraged.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (a hearty slap) Come go with me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet excitedly ushers Dave from the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim, smoke filled. Benvolio and Romeo play pool.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: (chalking his cue) Take thou some new infection to thy eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lines up the six ball top pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And the rank poison of the old will die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hopeless shot that slams the eight ball toward the side pocket. Romeo stops it with his hand and hurls it against the other balls.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Why, Romeo, art thou mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo sinks the other balls with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Not mad, but bound more than a madman is; Shut up in prison, kept without my food,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo stalks away from the table.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Whipped and tormented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops at the gun check, rummaging in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Good day, good fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crusty old man looks up from the small television. His entire face a tattooed shooting target, the bullseye betw his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man points to the sign that reads: "No ticket no gun." Romeo finally produces a ticket. Crusty the Target goes out back. Romeo's attention is caught by the televis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ostentatious woman and her over groomed partner Rich, hosts what looks to be a kind of Entertainment Tonight sh The graphic behind them reads "Solemnity Nights" with Sus Santandiago and Rich Ranchidis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan speaks conspiratorially to camera.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Now I'll tell you without asking. The great Rich Capulet, holds an old accustomed feast;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich chimes in:

dialogues.speaker: RICH
dialogues.text: A fair Assembly.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I Pray you sir can you read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A list of names begins to scroll across the screen. Rich reads them off.

dialogues.speaker: RICH
dialogues.text: Signor Placentio and his wife and daughters, Signor Martino, the Lady Widow Of Utruvio and her lovely nieces, Rosaline and Livia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Benvolio, he leans into Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: At this same ancient feast of

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET'S
dialogues.text: Sups the fair Rosaline; whom thou so loves, With all the admired beauties of Verona. Go thither, and with unattained eye Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: One fairer than my love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crusty returns. He hands the boys their guns.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: The all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: If you be not of the house of Montagues, Come and crush a cup of wine!

dialogues.speaker: RICH
dialogues.text: Rest you merry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo, he considers.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I'll go along, no such sight to be shown. But to rejoice in splendour of mine own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aerial shot of a magnificent island estate. An Italian wonder of Florentine architecture. Armed guards patrol th grounds. The telecaption reads "Capulet Mansion."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The file tape loses its television quality. We sweep down through manicured gardens, where workers prepare decorati for tonight's celebrations, and into the house. The music darkens and we hear the desperate calling of a girl's nam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: A long deserted corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: An echoey Chinoiserie style drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The still, serene, submerged features of a beautiful young girl. Dark floating hair gently frames th face. Heavy liquid eyes stare up through the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear, though faintly, the calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a rush JULIET surfaces. As she gulps air, we realise that she is in fact, in a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the calling loudly again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet listens. For a moment she is very still, then she closes her eyes and slides back beneath the surface of th water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Gothic, unfriendly environment heavy with religious iconography. The entrance hall is crowded with workers an servants preparing for tonight's party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria Capulet fiddles with a short black wig in the hall mirror. She is attired in full Cleopatra costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dissatisfied with the wig, she rips it from her head and calls maniacally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria is met by the NURSE, a fat, grandmotherly Hispanic woman.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Nurse, where's my daughter? Call her forth to me.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I bade her come. God forbid! Where's this girl? Juliet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The top of the stairs. As if from nowhere, Juliet has appeared. She wears a bathrobe and her hair is wet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (COOLLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam, I am here. What is you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria, startled, sweeps up the stairs and shuffles her daughter toward a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Nurse, give leave awhile, we must talk in secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria shepherds Juliet into her opulent dressing room an closes the door. She circles with nervous vexation search for words, stops, then suddenly opens the door and yells to the Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Nurse, come back again. I have remembered me, thou's hear our counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse enters. Gloria, still refusing eye contact, checks her appearance once more in the mirror. She takes hairbrush and, feigning pleasantness, intensely brushes h hair.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Nurse, thou knowest my daughter's of a pretty age.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (to Juliet) Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hair brush clatters onto the dresser. A moment of ten silence. Gloria grips herself and pours a sherry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back still turned, she speaks to her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: By my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nembutal twists like a pin in the corner of Gloria's mo She slugs it down with the sherry and turns abruptly to f Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Thus then in brief, the valiant Paris seeks you for his love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Juliet; an uncomprehending stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse, caught off guard, tries to buoy the situation.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: A man, young lady! Lady, such a

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: As all the world - why, he's a man of wax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The medication takes immediate effect upon Gloria. She joins Juliet on the couch and coos in Paris's favour.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Verona's summer hath not such a flower.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Nay, he's a flower; in faith, a very flower.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: This night you shall behold him at our feast; Read o'er the volume of young Paris' face And find delight writ there with beauty's pen. This precious book of love, this unbound lover, To beautify him only lacks a cover. So shall you share all that he doth possess, By having him, making yourself no less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria probes Juliet's thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Can you like of Paris' love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet, adept at negotiating her mother's strange moods, chooses her words precisely.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I'll look to like, if looking liking move, But no more deep will I endart mine eye, Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER the chauffeur enters.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Madam. The guests are come.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (checks the mirror) We follow thee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits, Nurse in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet stares out the windows and across the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the Nurse's face leers into shot. She whispers enthusiastically into Juliet's ear.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Go girl, seek happy nights to happy days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUMP CUT: Aerial shot of Capulet Mansion. We time lapse from late afternoon to night; fairy lights illuminate, guests appear, music swells, and a single incandescent flare, explodes pink against the inky sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo: his face glows pink. He is sitting on th grubby shoreline of Verona Bay dressed as a boy King Arth with fake chain mail and sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo watches the dying flare sink into the bay. The soun of the party drifts across the water. Balthasar, dressed Frankenstein's monster, touches a lighter to a large bong and Romeo inhales smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind them, Benvolio, drunk and dressed as a pizza, is yelling at Gregory, who, dressed as a Viking, is trying t cut slices off his pizza costume. Sampson, also dressed a a Viking, sits in the back of a car. One arm is bandaged and he swigs from a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the darkness is slashed by headlights. A reckles sports car speeds toward the boys. Stereo screaming, the car skids to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Music blares from the sound system. A silver stilettoed foot emerges from the car and plants itself firmly in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The boys, eyes wide with amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Another stiletto follows the first. Guitar groans

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN: Slowly up a shapely pair of black stockinged legs, p a hint of garter belt to a black sequined mini-skirt and over a muscular dark skinned stomach and tiny sequined br top, to discover: the 21 year old male, African American face of MERCUTIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The boys. Recovering from the initial shock, they laugh and cat-call raucously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Mercutio. He roughly jams a short black wig onto his head and yells above the music.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Strike drum!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio magically produces invitations from somewhere within his mini-skirt and dances down the beach to the bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aggressively bumping and grinding, Mercutio distributes t invitations. Reaching Romeo, he declares:

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: We'll on without apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo lets the invitation fall to the sand.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I am not for this ambling. Being but heavy, I will bear the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo pulls on the bong once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Mercutio is upon Romeo. Hauling him to his feet he waltzes him through the sand.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo pushes Mercutio away.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Not I, believe me. You have dancing shoes With nimble soles. I have a soul of lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio in mock sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Too great oppression for a tender thing.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Is love a tender thing? It is too rough, too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo lies staring up at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: If love be rough with you, be rough with love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio jumps on Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo fights Mercutio off.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Under love's heavy burden do I sink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Benvolio, impatiently honking the horn.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Every man betake him to his legs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio heads Romeo toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Come, we burn daylight, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: But 'tis no wit to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio turns, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Why, may one ask?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I dreamt a dream tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: And so did I.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Well, what was yours?

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: That dreamers often lie.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: In bed asleep, while they do dream things true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio produces a tiny gold pill case.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: O, then I see Queen Mab hath been with you. She is the fairies' midwife, and she comes In shape no bigger than an agate

dialogues.speaker: STONE
dialogues.text: On the forefinger of an alderman, Drawn with a team of little atomies Over men's noses as they lie asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tantalisingly, he passes the case beneath Romeo's nose.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Her chariot is an empty hazelnut, Her wagoner a small gray-coated gnat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a conjurer's dexterity Mercutio extracts a small, gr pill.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And in this state she gallops night by night Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He palms the pills. It reappears from behind Romeo's ear.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: O'er lawyers' fingers who straight dream on fees; O'er ladies' lips, who straight on kisses dream, Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues. Because their breaths with sweetmeats tainted are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pill box glints in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck; And then dreams he of cutting foreign throats. And being thus frighted, swears a prayer or two And sleeps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio now intensely angry:

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: This is that very Mab That plaits the manes of horses in the night And bakes the elf-locks in foul sluttish hairs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He screams into the night.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: This is the hag, when maids lie on their backs, That presses them and learns them first to bear, Making them women of good carriage. This is she, this is she...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Mercutio. He breaks off. There is a strange stillness amongst the group. Romeo goes to his friend.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace. Thou talkest of nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio meets Romeo's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: True, I talk of dreams; Which are the children of an idle brain, Begot of nothing but vain fantasy. Which is as thin of substance as the air And more inconstant than the wind, who woos Even now the frozen bosom of the

dialogues.speaker: NORTH
dialogues.text: And, being angered, puffs away from

dialogues.speaker: THENCE
dialogues.text: Turning his attention to the dew- dropping south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Benvolio in the car. The alcohol has caught up wi him and he looks a little queasy.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: This wind you talk of blows us from

dialogues.speaker: OURSELVES
dialogues.text: Supper is done and we shall come too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo looks toward the distant city.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I fear, too early, for my mind

dialogues.speaker: MISGIVES
dialogues.text: Some consequence yet hanging in the

dialogues.speaker: STARS
dialogues.text: Shall bitterly begin his fearful

dialogues.speaker: DATE
dialogues.text: With this night's revels, and expire the term Of a despised life closed in my breast, By some vile forfeit of untimely death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE: The water turns golden as fireworks explode across the bay. Romeo smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: But he that hath the steerage of my

dialogues.speaker: COURSE
dialogues.text: Direct my sail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the pill and drops it into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: On, lusty gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the rush of a mind altering cocktail, we ZOOM IN on Romeo's eyes; they shimmer with the shooting star reflect of exploding fireworks - a bending Eastern chord, we laun into Donna Summer's 'I Feel Love', sung by the vocalist f Soundgarden with orchestration by 'Deconstruction' and si by Ravi Shankar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL OUT: From Romeo's eyes. He is lying in the passenger seat of Mercutio's convertible as it rockets along the freeway. The camera is directly above Romeo. He stares up at the fireworks that reflect in the windshield. The car and freeway begin to rotate and the camera follows. We fe that the car is now travelling upside-down. The camera sways through a brilliant explosion of fireworks that fil the screen with a zillion pixilating, colored dots of fir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL OUT: To discover the glittering dots of fire refract from the sparkling domed roof of the magnificently ornate Capulet Ballroom. The camera swoops down over bizarrely costumed revellers cavorting to a driving Latin big band. The camera partners with a drugged Mercutio and Benvolio shamelessly caper with each other in a mock antic adagio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo gazing blankly at the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Mercutio. He sweeps up a thirty-something sophisticate and twirls her in Romeo's direction.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Everyman betake him to his legs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo moves off through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: ROMEO'S P.O.V.: Contorted images of costumed gues eat, drink and laugh in a grotesque collision of Yves Sai Laurent cocktail party and Bacchanalian romp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a large arm coils around Romeo's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISTORTED EXTREME CLOSE UP: A seriously intoxicated Fulge Capulet; his puffy red face squeezes against Romeo's.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Ah, I have seen the day that I

dialogues.speaker: COULD
dialogues.text: Tell a whispering tale in a fair ladies ear. Such as would please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet screams above the music:

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Come musicians play!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood drums in Romeo's ears. Breaking free from Capulet's grasp as he pushes through the crowd toward the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent, underwater shot. Romeo's tranquil features submer in a basin of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a gasp, Romeo rises. A moment. His breathing calms. Then, smoothing water into his hair, he gazes into the bathroom mirror. He turns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire wall opposite the mirror, is a magnificent sal water fish tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, drawn by it's submarine beauty, leans against the fish tank. Applause echoes faintly through the bathroom speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the applause dies, a dark-haired Latina Diva takes the spotlight. The band ease into the opening bars of a love ballad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the music swells, Romeo watches a moustached catfish glide past a medieval castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Romeo pulls away. Peering back at him through t castle is a pair of exquisitely beautiful angelic eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Diva's first pure, achingly beautiful notes soar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused, Romeo looks again. There is no mistake - it is girl. Through a shimmering curtain of ribbon weed, two da wide eyes, a childish nose and sumptuous full lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo pushes his face closer to the glass. The other face snaps abruptly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Juliet, dressed as an angel, on the other side of the tank. We now realise that the girls' powder room and the boys' bathroom are divided by this watery wonder worl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet warily moves closer to the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo leans his face against the glass. The love ballad builds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW TRACK: From Romeo's profile, in through the water, a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...out the other side, to find Juliet in profile, peering into the tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo presses his nose lightly against the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet; a tiny smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, CRASH! The door slams open. Juliet turns, startled. It is the Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Juliet, your mother calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse bustles Juliet out the door. Juliet looks over her shoulder at the mystery boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, now without his mask, slams out of the bathroom - Juliet and the Nurse have disappeared into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Juliet being dragged along by the Nurse. She glances back toward the mystery boy, but he is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet and the Nurse rejoin Dave Paris, who is dressed as astronaut, and Gloria, at the side of the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, irresistible smile, extends his hand to Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Will you now deny to dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet looks to Dave, desperately searching for a reason decline. Gloria, brushing aside her silly daughter's protests, slugs the last of her champagne and corrals the onto the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (whispering to Juliet) A man, young lady, such a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Juliet is dragged onto the floor her eyes furtively search for the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo in the crowd. Desperate to find the girl, h roughly shunts aside a reveller dressed as Lucifer, Princ of Darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON: Lucifer. He removes his mask: it is Tybalt. He turns to Abra, who's dressed as a demon.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: What, dares the slave come hither to fleer and scorn at our solemnity? Now by the stock and honor of my

dialogues.speaker: KIN
dialogues.text: To strike him dead I hold it not a sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt moves off aggressively, but is halted as Capulet slams a hand into his chest.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Why how now kinsman, wherefore storm you so?

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Uncle, this is that villain Romeo. A Montague, our foe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet peers across the ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Young Romeo is it?

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: 'Tis he.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Content thee gentle coz, let him alone. I would not for the wealth of all this town Here in my house do him disparagement. Therefore be patient; take no note of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: I'll not endure him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Capulet, exploding with rage.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: He shall be endured! (slapping Tybalt viciously) What, goodman boy! I say he shall! Go to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet violently shoves Tybalt to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: You'll make a mutiny among my guests!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle aged couple look on shocked - Capulet waves to t

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: What? Cheerly my hearts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet snorts at Tybalt in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: You'll not endure him! Am I the master here or you? Go to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoothing his hair into place, Capulet turns back into th ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Tybalt choking back tears of rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo moving through the crowd. For a moment the crush clears and he spies the Angel on the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo whispers:

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight. For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo begins to circumnavigate the dance floor in an atte to get closer to Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Dave slow dancing with Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet's eyes search the room for the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes connect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet looks quickly back to Dave who, oblivious, returns his most devastating smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The songstress, her voice soars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Juliet. Unable to look away from the boy, she stares over Dave's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo. Ignoring the danger, he continues to move toward the Angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the Diva's spiralling final notes, the ballad conclu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A complete black out. As the crowd break into wild applau Juliet's eyes search the darkness, but the boy is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd cheers and screams its applause. An avalanche o balloons, tinsel and confetti rains down from the roof; swathes of red silk drop from the ceiling and the space i transformed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet, searching for the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly: A gasp, Juliet's eyes widen, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dark, a hand has shot out from the drape curtainin off the stage and clasped hers. Juliet barely dares breat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances furtively to Dave Paris - he watches the stag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly Juliet turns toward the hand; there through a brea in the curtain she can see eye, cheek and lips of the mystery boy. As the Diva reprises the chorus, Romeo gentl pulls Juliet behind the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concealed from the party by the red velvet drape, hands still clasped, the teenagers are so close their bodies almost touch.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: If I profane with my unworthiest

dialogues.speaker: HAND
dialogues.text: This holy shrine, the gentle sin is this. My lips, two blushing pilgrims, ready stand To smooth that rough touch with a tender kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo moves his lips toward Juliet's. She stops him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this. For saints have hands that pilgrim's hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmers' kiss.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (a gentle scolding) Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do, They pray: grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Saints do not move, though grant for prayer's sake.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Then move not while my prayer's effect I take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Thus from my lips, by thine my sin is purged.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Sin from my lips? O trespass sweetly urged! Give me my sin again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: You kiss by th' book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a harsh light falls across the entwined couple. They break apart - Nurse has pulled open the curtain and stands eyeing them severely.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that the party is breaking up. But for groups of die-hard revellers, the room is nearly empty.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Come, let's away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes firm control of her charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet furtively motions for the startled Romeo not to follow as he trails them across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: ROMEO'S P.O.V.: The Nurse and Juliet reach the do but instead of leaving, they turn and ascend the staircas that arcs around to the mezzanine level. They join a vexe Gloria Capulet who clings to a patient Dave Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inaudible words are exchanged. Juliet flickers her eyes nervously to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo. He halts at the foot of the stairs unsure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Gloria. Catching Juliet's interest in the boy, sh indicates to her daughter to 'COME ALONG'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo; a dawning realisation.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Is she a Capulet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Juliet. She stops and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo, comprehending the reality of who she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Juliet. The Nurse whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: His name is Romeo, and a Montague, The only son of your great enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orchestral treatment of Joy Division's "Love will tear Apart" swells;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON: Juliet. Like a cloud passing across the sun, a dark coldness descends upon her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Mercutio. He throws himself upon the shell shocke Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Away, begone, the sport is at its best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio shuttles Romeo toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Ay so I fear,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A covert glance over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: The more is my unrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio bundles Romeo through the front door and down th stairs to the waiting getaway car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Juliet. Manoeuvred by the Nurse up the stairs, sh breaks away and rushes to a tiny, windowed alcove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Mercutio's convertible and its noisy confederacy joining the line of departing limos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge sign combusts into blinding fireworks that write i giant words "CAPULET."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the convertible passes beneath the blazing words, Rome turns. Through a deluge of falling sparks, he glimpses th mystery girl high up in the tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet leaning out of the tower window. Brillia sparkles light in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN: We hear her secret whisper:

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: My only love, sprung from my only hate. Too early seen unknown, and known too late. Prodigious birth of love it is to me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: JULIET'S P.O.V.: In slow motion Romeo, through th falling curtain of fiery embers.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: That I must love a loathed enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm wind blows the smoke from the expended fireworks. Juliet closes the window and leans against the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE DOWN: The side of the building past revellers who don't know when to leave. Standing in the front doorway i someone else who cannot take their eyes off the departing Romeo. It is Tybalt. The music darkens as we push through the smoky wind.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: I will withdraw. But this intrusion shall, Now seeming sweet, convert to bitterest gall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caught in the jam of departing vehicles, Mercutio's car crawls along the bridge that links Capulet island with th mainland. The boys sing along raucously with the radio.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: "I am a pretty piece of flesh, I am a pretty piece of flesh..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN: On Romeo, he whispers:

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Can I go forward when my heart is here? Turn back, dull earth, and find thy centre out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo leaps from the car. Benvolio yells after him.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Romeo! Cousin Romeo! Romeo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo runs back along the bridge toward the estate. At th gates, armed guards supervise the exodus of vehicles. Rom uses the traffic to shield himself from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo leaps from the bridge and into the shadows at the b of the high stone wall that borders the compound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio's car prowls back along the bridge. The last guests have departed and the gates are swinging shut. The convertible halts in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: He ran this way. Call, good Mercutio.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Nay, I'll conjure too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio leaps from the car. He postures like a magician a low-budget variety special. The boys cheer him on.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Romeo! Humours! Madman! Passion! Lover! I conjure thee by Rosaline's bright eyes, By her high forehead and her scarlet lip, By her fine foot, straight leg, and quivering thigh. And the demesnes that there adjacent lie, That in thy likeness thou appear to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo's fake chain mail shirt tangled in the barbed wire at the top of the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN DOWN: Romeo, now on the other side of the wall, pulls his undershirt and gingerly inspects the cuts inflicted b the wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio's cavorting echoes from the bridge. Romeo smiles ironically.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: He jests at scars that never felt a wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo moves off through the darkened grounds of Capulet estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys laugh hysterically as Mercutio staggers around t bridge in imitation of a love sick fool.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: O Romeo, that she were, O that she

dialogues.speaker: WERE
dialogues.text: An open-arse and thou a poperin pear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hilarity is abruptly arrested as a security spotlight blazes to life, pinning Mercutio in its beam. The sound o automatic weapons cocking pierces the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Mercutio. He's brave but not stupid. He gets back into the car.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Come, shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A pair of stone cherubs on top of the retaining wall of a terraced garden. Romeo's face appears between t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo hauls himself up onto the wall. Below is a Greco- Roman style pool area. To the right the darkened rear win of Capulet Mansion. Suddenly the back of the house explod with light. Romeo takes cover.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: But soft, what light through yonder window breaks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo's question is answered as out onto the verandah com Juliet. She is still clad in her angel robe, but without the halo and wings. She slowly descends to pool level.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: It is the East, and Juliet is the sun! Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon, Who is already sick and pale with

dialogues.speaker: GRIEF
dialogues.text: That thou her maid art far more fair than she. Be not her maid, since she is envious. Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it. Juliet stands on the top step of the pool stairs. She is directly below Romeo as he whispers.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Cast it off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet sits on the edge of the pool, her legs dangle in t water.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: It is my lady. O, it is my love! O that she knew she were!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet sighs.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Ay me!

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: (WHISPERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She speaks. O, speak again, bright angel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet looks longingly toward the stars.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O Romeo, Romeo! - Whyfore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name. Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, And I'll no longer be a Capulet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo. Incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: 'Tis but thy name that is my enemy. Thou are thyself, though not a Montague. What's Montague? It is not hand nor foot Nor arm nor face nor any other part Belonging to a man. O, be some other name! What's in a name? That which we call a rose By any other word would smell as sweet. So Romeo would, were he not Romeo called, Retain that dear perfection which he owes Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name, And for thy name, which is no part of thee, Take all myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo wildly calls:

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I take thee at thy word! Call me but love, and I'll be new baptised. Henceforth I never will be Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo jumps down from the wall. Juliet screams, and turns toppling backwards. Romeo grabs her hand but her momentum overbalances him and they both plunge headlong into the p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underwater shot: A slow motion phosphorescent tangle of arms, legs and bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: A security guard. Alerted by the noise he moves toward the pool area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Above water, real time: Romeo and Juliet surface spluttering. Juliet thrashes the water in an attempt to g distance from her attacker.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night, So stumblest on my counsel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo: A calming gesture as he tries to tread water.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am: My name, dear saint, is hateful to

dialogues.speaker: MYSELF
dialogues.text: Because it is an enemy to thee. The ferocious barking of a guard dog arrests the teenager attention. A moment, then they slide beneath the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The security guard and dog appearing above the po area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUARD'S P.O.V.: The rippling surface of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO - UNDERWATER SHOT: Romeo and Juliet submerged, hai streaming, stare at each other like two beautiful fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The guard. He can see noisy caterers cleaning up around the other side of the house. Frowning, he returns the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo and Juliet. Gasping for air, they cautiousl surface. A moment - then Juliet, a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Neither, fair maid, if either thee dislike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet looks nervously toward the house. She drags Romeo toward a small grotto at the end of the pool.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: How cam'st thou hither, tell me, and whyfore? The garden walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: (with splashy bravado) With love's light wings did I o'er perch these walls. For stony limits cannot hold love out, And what love can do, that dares love attempt. Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet drags Romeo firmly into the grotto.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (a real fear) If they do see thee, they will murder thee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo slowly pulls Juliet toward him.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I have night's cloak to hide me from their eyes. And but thou love me, let them find me here. My life were better ended by their

dialogues.speaker: HATE
dialogues.text: Than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lovers kiss long and deep. Then Juliet, suddenly fearful, pushes Romeo away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Thou knowest the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek, For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight. Fain would I dwell on form - fain, fain deny What I have spoke. But farewell compliment! Dost thou love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo tries to speak, Juliet silences him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I know thou wilt say 'Ay', and I will take thy word. Yet, if thou swearest, Thou mayst prove false. O gentle Romeo, If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully. Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won, I'll frown, and be perverse, and say thee nay, So thou wilt woo. But else, not for the world. In truth, fair Montague, I am too fond, And therefore thou mayst think my 'haviour light. But trust me, gentleman, I'll prove more true Than those that have more cunning to be strange.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Lady, by yonder blessed moon I vow, That tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops -

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O, swear not by the moon, th' inconstant moon, That monthly changes in her circled orb, Lest that thy love prove likewise variable.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: What shall I swear by?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Do not swear at all. Or if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I'll believe thee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his cheek. Romeo moves his lips close.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: If my heart's dear love -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused, Juliet breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Well, do not swear. Although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract tonight. It is too rash, too unadvised, too SUDDEN; Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say 'it lightens.' Sweet, good night. This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet. Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes up the stairs - Romeo follows desperately.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet - a shocked look.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet. She runs joyously to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I gave thee mind before thou didst request it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissing him passionately.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And yet I would it were to give again.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Wouldst thou withdraw it? For what purpose love?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But to be frank and give it thee again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss again. The Nurse calls from inside.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Juliet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet looks to the house.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (BREATHLESSLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed. If that thy bent of love be honourable.
