Thy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow, By one that I'll procure to come to thee, Where and what time thou wilt perform the rite, And all my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay And follow thee my lord throughout the world.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Madam!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I come, anon - But if thou meanest not well, I do beseech thee...

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Madam!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (to Nurse) By and by I come! To cease thy strife and leave me to my grief. Tomorrow will I send.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo holds Juliet's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: So thrive my soul.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Madam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: A thousand times good night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a final kiss, Juliet runs inside.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: A thousand times the worse, to want thy light. Love goes toward love as schoolboys from their books; But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet re-appears at the upper balcony.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Romeo! What o'clock tomorrow Shall I send to thee?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: By the hour of nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet unclasps a delicate silver necklace from around he neck.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I will not fail. 'Tis twenty year till then. Goodnight, goodnight! Parting is such sweet sorrow. That I shall say goodnight till it be morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets the necklace fall from her hand. Romeo catches i and she is gone.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast, Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning sunlight filters through the lush foliage of a tropical rainforest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN DOWN: As we hear:

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: O mickle is the powerful grace that

dialogues.speaker: LIES
dialogues.text: In plants, herbs, stones, and their true qualities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We discover the intensely concentrating features of FATHE LAURENCE. Fifties, wiry and wearing a priest's collar, Laurence delicately makes an incision in the bulb of a sm purple flowered plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of fresh faced ten year old boys look on in wonder as a vivid blue sap oozes from the incision.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Within the infant rind of this weak

dialogues.speaker: FLOWER
dialogues.text: Poison hath residence, and medicine power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: The Priest carefully gathers the sap into a beaker. We discover that we are in a small tropical greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (to the boys) For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part; Being tasted, stays all senses with the heart. The boys follow the Father as he moves out of the greenho and into an adjoining work area. The walls are lined with bottles of herbs and dried plants and a television flicke in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: For naught so vile on the earth doth live, But to the earth some special good doth give;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the precision of a chemist, Father Laurence funnels sap into a small bottle and places it in the refrigerator From out of the refrigerator he produces a large jar of candy. He eyes the boys sternly.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Nor aught so good but, strained from that fair use, Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys take their candy and scram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The muted television. A morning news program show footage of a murder scene cordoned off with police tape. distraught mother is being restrained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The priest contemplating the television.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Two such opposed kings encamp them

dialogues.speaker: STILL
dialogues.text: In man as well as herbs: grace and rude will; And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feverish knocking breaks the priest's reverie.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Good morrow, father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence snaps off the television and exits the workroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, dressed in last night's chain mail, pounds despera on a wooden door set into a high stone wall.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Good morrow, father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the workroom, Father Laurence enters a courtyard whi encloses a tranquil tropical garden. He opens a door in t wall of the courtyard and smiles as the costumed Romeo bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Benedicite! What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without pausing, the priest continues through the courtya and toward the church.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Young son, it argues a distempered

dialogues.speaker: HEAD
dialogues.text: So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed. Or if not so, then here I hit it right - Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest enters the back of the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, on fire to tell of his experience, follows the pri into the sacristy.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: The last is true. The sweeter rest was mine.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (he stops) God pardon sin! Wast thou with Rosaline?

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: With Rosaline, my ghostly father? No. I have forgot that name and that name's woe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Father lays out the cut glass bottles and communion t for mass.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: That's my good son! But where hast thou been then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unconsciously, Romeo helps the priest prepare. It is clea he knows the routine by heart.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I have been feasting with mine enemy, Where on a sudden one hath wounded me. That's by me wounded. Both our

dialogues.speaker: REMEDIES
dialogues.text: Within they help and holy physic lies.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (buttoning a long black cassock) Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift. Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Then plainly know my heart's dear love is set, On the fair daughter of rich Capulet. We met, we wooed, and made exchange of vow, I'll tell thee as we pass. But this I pray, That thou consent to marry us today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The Priest, thunderstruck. The two kids, now dressed in red altar-boy robes, enter.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAR BOYS
dialogues.text: Good morrow, Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apoplectic priest waves the boys away. They get the message and bolt.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Holy Saint Francis! What a change is here! Is Rosaline, that thou didst love so dear, So soon foresaken? Young men's love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (very angry) For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I pray thee chide me not. Her I love now Doth grace for grace and love for love allow. The other did not so.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: O, she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Father falls into a chair and considers. He looks through the sacristy door to where a small children's cho has assembled. Their angelic voices soar into the purest hymns.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR
dialogues.text: How can you just leave me standing Alone in a world so cold, Maybe I'm just too demanding, Maybe I'm just like my father, too bold, Maybe you're just like my mother, She's never satisfied. Why do we scream at each other? This is what it sounds like when doves cry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We recognise the hymn as "When Doves Cry" by Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN: On the Priest; moved, he looks to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: But come, young waverer, come, go with me. In one respect I'll thy assistant be. For this alliance may so happy

dialogues.speaker: PROVE
dialogues.text: To turn your households' rancor to pure love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo hurriedly assists the priest with his vestments.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: O, let us hence! I stand on sudden haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence holds Romeo in his powerful gaze.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Wisely and slow. They stumble that run fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The procession is joined by the two little altar boys and the mass begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Angelic voices of the choir soar, we see a pay pho etched with hyper-real starkness against the white sand, green sea and blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single leaning palm tree frames the image like a ridicu tourist postcard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio speaks on the pay phone. Mercutio, torso naked b for his holstered Sports Rapier 9mm, drums his fingers on the side of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Where the devil should this Romeo be? Came he not home tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: (slamming down the phone) Not to his father's. I spoke with his man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio storms off down the beach.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so that he will sure run mad.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: (running to keep up) Tybalt hath sent a letter to his father's house.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (halts abruptly) A challenge, on my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Benvolio, unsure.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Romeo will answer it?

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Any man that can write may answer a letter.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Nay, he will answer the letter's master, how he dares, being dared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio clamps Benvolio into a headlock.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Alas, poor Romeo, he is already dead! Stabbed with a white wench's black eye,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whispers into Benvolio's ear:

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Run through the ear with a love song. (in disgust) And is he a man to encounter Tybalt?

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: (struggling to break free) Why, what is Tybalt?

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (releasing him) More than Prince of Cats, I can tell you. O, he's the courageous captain of compliments. The very butcher of a silk button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightening fast, Mercutio draws his gun. He twirls it in impressive display of gunmanship which ends with the barr between the startled Benvolio's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: A duellist, a duellist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo's car pulls into the beach side parking lot. Benvol heads toward it.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo alights from his car and throws his keys to Balthas who lounges outside the beach side hang. Mercutio saunter up the beach with mock nonchalance.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Signor Romeo, Bonjour. There's a French salutation to your French slop. You gave us the counterfeit fairly last night.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Good morrow to you both. What counterfeit did I give you?

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: The slip, sir, the slip. Can you not conceive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo smiles smugly.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Pardon, good Mercutio. My business was great, and in such a case as mine a man may strain courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (SARCASTICALLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A most courteous exposition.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Nay I am the very pink of courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (CAMPLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink for flower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys laugh. Romeo feigns anger.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I will bite thee on the ear for that jest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio, goading Romeo to follow, backs off down the bea

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Come between us, good Benvolio! My wits faint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio flicks sand at Romeo, then sprints off down the beach. Romeo, laughing, gives chase.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I'll cry a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo is gaining on Mercutio, who runs headlong into the With a yell, Romeo dives in after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio splashes the laughing Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo tries to dunk Mercutio.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Now art thou sociable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio, evading, heads for shore.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Now art thou Romeo. Now art thou...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo tackles Mercutio on the wet sand. Mercutio falls suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (QUIETLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What thou art, by art as well as by nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment between the boys. A shadow falls across them. Romeo looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Here's goodly gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing above the boys is the Nurse. She wears a ridiculous, all red, "Jackie O" style disguise of sunglas scarf and parasol.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (BEMUSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God ye good e'en fair gentlewoman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse, ignoring Mercutio, speaks dramatically to Rome

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I desire some confidence with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and walks back to the parking lot where Peter t chauffer waits beside the limousine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio and the other boys look on curiously.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: A bawd, a bawd, a bawd! So ho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Romeo rises and to the amazement of Mercutio actually follows this woman. Mercutio looks questioningly to Benvolio, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: She will endite him to some supper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even more strangely, Romeo gets into the limousine.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (taken by surprise) Romeo, will you come to your father's? We'll to dinner thither.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: (as he closes the door) I will follow you.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Farewell, ancient lady. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine drives through Verona Beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo jammed into the corner of the seat. The Nurse's face is pressed alarmingly close to his. She spea in cold deadly earnest.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: If ye should lead her in a fool's paradise, as they say, it were a very gross kind of behavior, as they say. For the gentlewoman is young; and therefore, if you should deal double with her, truly it were an ill thing and very weak dealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEAT: Romeo chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Bid her to come to confession this afternoon, And there she shall at Friar Laurence's cell Be shrived and (PUSH IN ON: Romeo) married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet's face peering out her bedroom window.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O God she comes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: JULIET'S P.O.V.: The limousine pulls up at the front door, the Nurse alights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet bolts from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet hurries down the stairs - the Nurse, a way ahead, disappears into a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet races down a dark stairwell that leads to the bowe of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen, obviously the Nurse's domain, is decorated w a mixture of religious iconography and travel posters. Mo of the posters depict a strange city of decadent, decayin beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet bursts breathlessly into the room.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O honey nurse, what news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse, buried up to her ample hips inside the refrigerator, does not turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet cries impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Nurse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse emerges from the ice box laden with food. Movin to the counter she starts to make a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I am aweary, give me leave awhile. Fie, how my bones ache. What a jaunce have I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet goes to the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Nay come, I pray thee, speak: good;

dialogues.speaker: GOOD
dialogues.text: Nurse, speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandwich made, the nurse shuffles over to a corner couch.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Jesu, what haste. Can you not stay awhile? Can you not see I am out of breath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet cannot stand the suspense any longer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath! Is the news good or bad? Answer to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse takes a big bite from her sandwich and answers through thoughtful chews.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Well, you have made a simple choice. You know not how to choose a man. Romeo? No, not he. Though his face be better than any man's, yet his leg excels all men's and for a hand and a foot and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare. He's not the flower of courtesy, but I'll warrant him as gentle as a lamb. Go thy ways, wench, serve God. What, have you dined at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: No, no. But all this I did know before. What says he of our marriage? What of that

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Lord how my head aches! What a head have I: My back -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a game that Juliet knows well. She moves behind t Nurse and begins massaging her back.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: o' t'other side - ah, my back! Beshrew your heart for sending me

dialogues.speaker: ABOUT
dialogues.text: To catch my death with jauncing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With sublime self control, Juliet coo's sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I'faith I am sorry that thou art not well. Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what says my love?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Your love says like an honest gentleman, And a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, And I warrant a virtuous - Where is your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet cracks.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Where is my mother? How oddly thou repliest! 'Your love says, like an honest gentleman, "Where is your mother"'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse sulks.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: O God's lady dear are you so hot? Henceforth do your messages yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet's frustration explodes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Here's such a coil! COME WHAT SAYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE: The Nurse considers Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Have you got leave to go to confession today?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Then hie you hence to Father Laurence cell. There stays a husband to make you a wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet, with a scream of joy, hugs the Nurse to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD ON: Juliet's ecstatic features.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: These violent delights have violent ends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: Father Laurence is preaching energetically fro the pulpit. Hidden from the congregation, Romeo waits in small alcove chapel at the side of the altar.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: The sweetest honey Is loathsome in its own deliciousness, Therefore love moderately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Father glances toward Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Long love doth so. Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow. Juliet pushes through the double doors at the far end of church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence motions to the middle-aged choir master w leads the choir into a choral version of Led Zeppelin's " Whole Lot of Love" with Latin lyrics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence hurries from the altar over to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Here comes the lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet bursts into the tiny chapel. Trying to observe a vestige of decorum, she greets Father Laurence.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Good afternoon to my ghostly confessor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before the priest can reply, the two lovers embrace, kissing passionately.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (DRYLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir completes the hymn and the priest, realising it his cue, rushes back to the altar. He quickly delivers a prayer to the congregation while eyeing the increasingly amorous smooching of the young couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir launch into a joyous chorus and the priest retu to Romeo and Juliet. He delicately parts the couple.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Come, come, and we will make short work. For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone Till Holy Church incorporate two in one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young boy with a voice like Jamiroquai steps forward. H launches into a wailing solo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MACRO CLOSE UP: A simple silver ring. Engraved on the inside of the band are the words 'I love thee.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: Romeo slips the ring onto Juliet's finger as t priest executes the formal sacrament of marriage. INT./EXT. CHURCH. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE UP: Through the majestic patterning of stained glas and out of the church to find Peter, the chauffeur, cradl a small camera as he waits nervously beside the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music swells in celebration. Romeo and Juliet, now newly-wed, rush from the side door of the church. The priest follows, throwing handfuls of rice. Peter studious takes a snap as the bride and groom kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter holds the door of the limousine open. Reluctantly Juliet gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car pulls out of the driveway, Romeo runs alongsid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD: On Romeo as he watches the big black car speed away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FISH-EYE VIEW: From the bottom of the ocean; Mercutio's distorted features. Gun aimed, he stares intently into th water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A muffled BANG! and a bullet whizzes past the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that Mercutio - wading in knee deep water close to the beach - is hunting fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio shelters in the shade of an unmanned life guard tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shimmering heat haze blankets the deserted beach and th horizon is stacked with purple storm clouds.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire. The day is hot,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio, ignoring him, plugs away at another fish. Benvo nervously looks to see if there is any reaction to the so of the shot.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: The Capels are abroad. And if we meet we shall not 'scape a brawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio strides out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Thou art like one of these fellows that, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword upon the table and says 'God send me no need of thee!' (he hands Benvolio his gun) and by the operation of the second cup draws him on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another incredible sleight of hand routine and Mercutio h managed to draw Benvolio's pistol, retrieve his own gun, trap Benvolio with a barrel at each temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joke has worn thin for Benvolio; he pushes past Mercu toward where Balthasar, Sampson and Gregory lounge in the shade of the beach-side hang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he stops dead - a monstrous black sedan prowls i the beach side parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: By my head, here comes the Capulets.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: By my heel, I care not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sedan mounts the curb and slides to a halt only metre from Benvolio and Mercutio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt, Abra and Petruchio alight from the sedan and walk menacingly toward Mercutio and Benvolio.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, good day. A word with one of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys from the hang, drawn the Capulet car, converge - eyes dart nervously, hands stray towards guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio smiles mockingly.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: And but one word with one of us? Couple it with something. Make it a word and a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaning close to Tybalt, he camps the implication.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: ...blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio scores. The boys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: (FURIOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, (clutching at his side arm) And you will give me occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Mercutio. He stops, eyeing the hand on the gun. No one moves.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (a breathy, coquettish

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Could you not take some occasion without giving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys fall about again. Tybalt cracks.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Mercutio, thou consortest with Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The accusation stings - Mercutio's anger flares.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Consort? What, dost thou make us minstrels? And thou make minstrels of us look to hear nothing but discords. Here's my fiddlestick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indicating his holstered gun.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Here's that shall make you dance. (barking at Tybalt) Zounds, (goading him to go for his gun) consort!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Tybalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Mercutio. He will not back down. Benvolio tries to diffuse things.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Either withdraw unto some private place. Or reason coldly of your grievances. Here all eyes gaze on us.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze. I will not budge for no man's pleasure, I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, Romeo's car pulls into the lot. Tybalt smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Well sir, here comes my man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt moves toward Romeo who bounds from his car full of happy news.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Romeo, the love I bear thee can

dialogues.speaker: AFFORD
dialogues.text: No better term than this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Tybalt. He clears his jacket from his side arm and issues the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Thou art a villain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Mercutio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Benvolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are on Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo calmly approaches his now cousin.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining

dialogues.speaker: RAGE
dialogues.text: To such a greeting: villain am I none, Therefore farewell. I see thou knowest me not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo turns, and to the amazement of all, walks back to h car. Tybalt, unable to shoot him in the back, is confused He hurls himself into his sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kicking it into a sand spraying U-turn, he careens the sh distance to Romeo's car. Slamming into the back of it he blocks Romeo in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt leaps out, maniacally kicking at bumper, door and headlights. Romeo flicks the locks down. Tybalt shatters the side window and hauls Romeo through the door, slammin him against the savaged fuselage.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Boy, this shall not excuse the

dialogues.speaker: INJURIES
dialogues.text: That thou hast done me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smashes Romeo across the face, Romeo crashes to the roadway.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: (YELLING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn and draw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cut has opened in the side of Romeo's mouth. He unstead lifts himself up, and meeting Tybalt's gaze, speaks throu bloodied teeth.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I never injured thee, And so, good Capulet, which name I

dialogues.speaker: TENDER
dialogues.text: As dearly as mine own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo cautiously extracts his gun...

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: ...be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and throws it at Tybalt's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storm clouds obscure the sun as Romeo turns and walks fro the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio, Benvolio and the others cannot believe their ey

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: O calm, dishonourable, vile submission!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt's anger must be answered. He ceremoniously disarms gives his weapon to Abra, and sprints after Romeo who is passing a beach side lot that houses an abandoned grand hotel. A bone-cracking kick sends Romeo crumbling into th vacant lot. The boys swarm toward the fray. Romeo, still refusing the fight, scrambles up the stairs the deserted hotel. Tybalt trips him and Romeo careens in an ornamental wooden railing, smashing it to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt kicks savagely at the helpless Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Mercutio appears running full tilt down the concrete terrace. He plucks up one of the splintered wood palings and yells...

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Tybalt, you ratcatcher,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as he bludgeons him across the face. Tybalt goes down.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Will you walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt leaps to his feet grabbing a lump of wood.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: What wouldst thou have with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swipes at Mercutio.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: (AVOIDING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio jabs, Tybalt sidesteps.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: I am for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt aims a double-handed blow to Mercutio's head. Mercutio blocks, hooking Tybalt's stick away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unarmed, Tybalt throws his full body weight upon Mercutio slamming him against a window that shatters in a storm of glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning fast, Mercutio jackknifes to his feet. He raise his weapon to deliver a skull-crushing final blow to the trapped Tybalt. Romeo rushes between them.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Forbear this outrage, good Mercutio!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seizing the opportunity, Tybalt lunges at Romeo with a lethal triangle of broken glass. He misses, gouging inste a slash of flesh from Mercutio's stomach. A scream of excruciating pain as Mercutio grabs at his bloodied side. Everyone is still. In the abrupt silence, sirens are heard closing in the distance. Abra tugs at Tybalt.

dialogues.speaker: ABRA
dialogues.text: Away Tybalt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They bolt for their vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio goes to Mercutio.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Art thou hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mercutio, covering his wound with his hand, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: Ay, ay, a scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to his assembled fans at the bottom of the stair With outrageous bravado he plays at being Caesar the conqueror.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: A scratch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys cheer their conquering hero. Romeo helps Mercuti down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Courage, man. The hurt cannot be much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio holding his bleeding side, jokes through the pai

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: 'Twill serve. Ask for me tomorrow and you shall find me a grave man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the next thought to the assembled audience.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (through crazy laughter) A plague o' both your houses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio turns from the cheering boys to Romeo who is struggling to support his weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio - through weak and desperate breathing.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Why the devil came you between us? I was hurt under your arm. Romeo starts to register the panic in Mercutio's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I thought all for the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like an animal trying to break free from a mortal trap, Mercutio pushes Romeo away. He screams in horror, as if falling in the dark:

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO
dialogues.text: A plague o' both your houses! They have made worms' meat of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercutio staggers down the stairs and collapses in the di Romeo is there instantly, cradling his friend's head out the dust. The dying boy stares back at Romeo, smiling through the chilling cold.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (a silent whisper) Your houses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything stands still, everything is quiet. The storm finally breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny drops of water fall from the sky and bespeckle Mercutio's lifeless body. The droplets grow to a heavy ra Romeo can hear the faint sound a thousand miles away of Benvolio whispering:

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Mercutio is dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears streak Romeo's face. He cries out.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Oh sweet Juliet, Thy beauty hath made me effeminate And in my temper softened valor's steel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of Tybalt's vehicle starting brings back cold reality. Romeo's sorrow turns to uncontrollable rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrugging aside Benvolio's attempts to restrain him, Rome runs to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead Tybalt's sedan screeches into a fishtailing U-tu and powers away. Romeo jumps into his vehicle. In an effort to head Tybalt off, he guns his damaged machine down a one way street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain is now blinding. Romeo stops for nothing; pedestrians flee, cars spin out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AERIAL SHOT: The two cars speed along parallel roads towa Plaza Jesu. Romeo is gaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Tybalt's car negotiating the immense roundabout a the foot of the statue of Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo's car firing out of the one way street and slamming into Tybalt's car. Tybalt's car careens out of control up the stairs of the statue, clips the fountain, flips, and slides upside down onto the roadway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Tybalt scrambling from his upturned vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo running toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY Romeo is halted by Tybalt's drawn gun. Fearlessl marching toward it, he screams through tears.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Mercutio's soul Is but a little way above our heads,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo grabs the barrel of the gun; forcing it between his own eyes, he growls insanely at Tybalt.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Staying for thine to keep him company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tybalt, unnerved, tries to back off.

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Thou, wretched boy, shalt with him hence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, refusing to let go of the gun, forces Tybalt backw through the torrential rain.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: (with frightening intensity) Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars swerve, Romeo is relentless. He grips Tybalt's hand trying to force him to shoot.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panicked, Tybalt wrenches free and lurches onto the roadw Blinded by the headlights of an oncoming car he thuds ont its hood as it skids to a halt. The impact catapults his gun high into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo coldly follows its slow motion, spinning trajectory

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real time stretches as the gun dances high above his head Police sirens, cars swerving, people screaming, and the yelling of panicked commands fade to a nothingness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo stands calmly considering the gun in the air. A harrowing symphonic tone and the echo of Mercutio's voice can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: MERCUTIO, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Why the devil came you between us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Patrol cars sliding to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The spinning gun slowly falling to earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Tybalt rising from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Cops leaping from their cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The gun landing in Romeo's hand. His eyes full of rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Cops levelling their revolvers.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (Romeo in his sights) Put up thy weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Real time - Romeo fires three deliberate shots. Tybalt's body convulses backwards against the car, hittin it with a thud, bloodying the shattered windscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop fires. A bullet grazes Romeo's arm - his gun drop as he screams.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: O, I am fortune's fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment a roaring hurricane wind hits; blinding po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The scaffolding surrounding the Jesus statue. Part of it's canvas covering rips away. Scaffold rains do as the insanely flapping material tries to smash free fro it's moorings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the mayhem, a rusty Ford driven by Balthasar, sli to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balthasar screams out at Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: BALTHASAR
dialogues.text: Romeo, away be gone! Stand not amazed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo collapses into the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops open fire as Balthasar speeds off into the storm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo is bleeding from the bullet graze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gale-force winds throw waves across the causeway as t fugitives disappear into the black afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE UP: In the distance we see Montague and Capulet tow Divided by the statue of Christ, they suffer the storm's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away, below the outstretched arms of Christ, lights from emergency vehicles pulse red through the downpour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA: Falls through heavy rain toward a woman crouc over the lifeless body of Tybalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cries:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Tybalt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops nervously eye Fulgencio Capulet and Ted Montague, wh both flanked by body guards, face each other across the crime scene. Medics stand by helplessly as Gloria clings Tybalt's body. A handcuffed Benvolio looks on.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Tybalt, my cousin, O my brother's child! O, the blood is spilled of my dear kinsman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police lines part as Captain Prince arrives.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benvolio struggles forward.

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: O noble Prince I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria appeals hysterically:

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Prince as thou art true, For blood of ours shed blood of Montague!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: (pointing to Tybalt's corpse) There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman brave Mercutio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria interjects savagely.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: He speaks not true! Affection makes him false!

dialogues.speaker: BENVOLIO
dialogues.text: Romeo, that spoke him fair, could not take Truce with the unruly spleen of

dialogues.speaker: TYBALT
dialogues.text: Deaf to peace!

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: He is a kinsman to the Montague! I beg for justice which thou Prince must give. Romeo slew Tybalt, Romeo must not live!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Prince turns to Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio. Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Montague pleads:

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: Not Romeo, Prince, he was Mercutio's friend; His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Prince eyes Montague coldly.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: And for that offence Immediately we do exile him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montague, body guards in tow, surges forward.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGUE
dialogues.text: Noble Prince...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince silences him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE
dialogues.text: I will be deaf to pleading and EXCUSES; Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses. Therefore use none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain turns and addresses his assembled officers.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Let Romeo hence in haste, Else, when he is found that hour is his last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Captain Prince.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN PRINCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Bear hence this body and attend our will. Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An acoustic guitar version of Joy Division's 'Love Will T Us Apart.' Juliet traces the path of a raindrop on the window pane as she speaks her thoughts to the storm.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Come gentle night, coming loving black browed night, Give me my Romeo. And when I shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night, And pay no worship to the garish sun. O, I have bought the mansion of a

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: But not possessed it, and though I am sold, Not yet enjoyed. So tedious is this day As is the night before some festival To an impatient child that hath new

dialogues.speaker: ROBES
dialogues.text: And may not wear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet's P.O.V.: The limousine pulls into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL OUT: Of the window and CRANE DOWN: Juliet runs from room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the open doorway we see an excited Juliet meet th Nurse at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music surges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK IN: The Nurse's words are lost in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet buckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are close enough now to hear Juliet's words.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh God! Did Romeo's hand shed Tybalt's blood?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It did, it did! Alas the day, it did!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Oh serpent heart, hid with a flowering face. Was ever book containing such vile

dialogues.speaker: MATTER
dialogues.text: So fairly bound? O, that deceit should dwell In such a gorgeous palace!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: There's no trust, No faith, no honesty in men. All perjured, All forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers. Shame come to Romeo.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Blistered be thy tongue For such a wish! He was not born to shame. Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband? Ah, poor my lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name When I, thy three-hours wife have mangled it? But whyfore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin? That villain cousin would have killed my husband. All this is comfort, wherefore weep I then? Some word there was worser than Tybalt's death: I would forget it fain - exiled. Tybalt is dead, and Romeo exiled. To speak that word is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, all slain, All dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet sinks to the floor, overwhelmed by tears.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Nurse, I'll to my wedding bed, And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse looks down at Juliet. She goes and comforts her.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Hie to your chamber. I'll find

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: To comfort you. I know well where he is. Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet looks up through tears.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O find him, give this ring to my true knight, And bid him come to take his last farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAM MACRO ZOOM: Into the ring. The screen fills with the words 'I love thee'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo lies on the bed shirtless and crying. His wound has been bandaged and Balthasar crouches frightened in the co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest leads the Nurse into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Nurse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Ah sir! Ah sir! Death's the end of all.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Speakest thou of Juliet? Where is she? And how doth she? And what says My concealed lady to our cancelled love?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: O, she says nothing, sir, but weeps and weeps, And then on Romeo cries, and then falls down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo is wailing inconsolably.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her, as that name's cursed hand murdered her kinsman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence shakes the hysterical boy.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: I thought thy disposition better tempered! Thy Juliet is alive, There art thou happy. The law that threatened death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile. There art thou happy. A pack of blessings light upon thy back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo calms. The Nurse gives him the ring.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Here sir, a ring my lady bid me give you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo enfolds the ring in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: How well my comfort is revived by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest goes to his wardrobe, removes a clean white sh and helps Romeo put it on.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed. Ascend her chamber. Hence and comfort her. But look thou stay not till the Watch be set, For then thou canst not pass to Mantua where thou shalt live till we can find a time To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends, Beg pardon of the Prince and call thee back, With twenty hundred thousand times more joy Than thou wentst forth in lamentation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence ushers Romeo from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurry down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Go hence. Be gone by the break of

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Sojourn in Mantua. Give me thy hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest and Balthasar watch as Romeo and the Nurse spr for the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sobs echo through the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave Paris stands in the entrance hallway clutching a hug bunch of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fulgencio Capulet stands beside him, whisky glass in hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Gloria on the upper landing. There is a strange faraway quality about her as she descends to Dave and Cap

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: She'll not come down tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, an understanding smile.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: These times of woe afford no times to woo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet guides Dave into the house.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (JOINING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so did I.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: (a cold glance at Gloria) Well, we were born to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet takes a large slug of whisky. Gloria leans close Dave.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: I'll know her mind early tomorrow. Tonight she's mewed up to her heaviness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gloria, Dave and Capulet exit down the hallway we CRAN UP: toward Juliet's bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet's face. Tears stream onto the pillow. Without warning a hand lightly touches her cheek. Juliet' eyes dart up to discover Romeo standing above her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A still moment of disbelief. Leaning down, Roemo kisses away the tears that fall from her dark, wide eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet's lips find Romeo's and they gently sink back onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet sits in an armchair drinking. Dave and Gloria sit opposite as Capulet whips himself into a frenzy of drunke excitement.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: We'll keep no great ado - a friend or two. For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman if we revel much - But soft what day is this?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Monday my lord.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Well Wednesday is too soon - what say you to Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria looks up alarmed; Dave is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My lord I...

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: (leaning close) I will make a desperate tender of my child's love. (a drunken good humour) I think she will be ruled in all respects by me; (exploding with hearty laughter) Nay, more, I doubt it not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Gloria, her face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: (to Dave) But what say you to Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave is trying to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My lord I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Capulet he eyes Dave intently.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I would that Thursday were tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delighted, Capulet jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: A Thursday let it be then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet holds out his glass in toast. Dave and Gloria ris

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Wife, go you to Juliet ere you go to bed. Tell her, a Thursday she shall be

dialogues.speaker: MARRIED
dialogues.text: To this noble sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The glasses clink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pink and gold dawn breaks over Capulet Mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tangle of young limbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo and Juliet blissfully asleep. The dawn light creeps into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balthasar's car covertly pulls into a side road near the estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo and Juliet still asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE DOWN: Toward the sleeping innocence of the faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD: A shadow of fear passes across Romeo's features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a cry of panic, he sits bolt upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide awake, but disorientated, Romeo stares around the room - as Juliet stirs, he remembers where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slipping quietly from the bed, Romeo begins to dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Romeo. A pair of lips enter frame and find his neck. It is Juliet. She hugs herself to him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo turns - softly he strokes her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I must be gone and live, or stay and die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet kisses his finger-tips.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Yond light is not daylight,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then his cheek...

dialogues.speaker: JULIET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I know it, I It is some meteor that the sun

dialogues.speaker: EXHALES
dialogues.text: To light thee on thy way to Mantua. Therefore stay yet. Thou needest not to be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo, feverishly returning the kisses, throws himself on Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Let me be taken, let me be put to death. I have more care to stay than will to go. Come, death, and welcome! Juliet wills it so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet is suddenly still. Romeo kisses her gently.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: How is't, my soul? Let's talk. It is not day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet pulls Romeo to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: It is, it is! Hie hence, be gone, away! O, now be gone! More light and light it grows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frantically she helps him into his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: More light and light: more dark and dark our woes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an urgent knocking on the door. They freeze.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Madam!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Nurse!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Then, window, let day in, and let life out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desperately Juliet pulls Romeo out onto the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm, now past, has left a morning achingly pure.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Farewell, farewell. One kiss, and I'll descend. Romeo climbs down from the balcony and into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O, think'st thou we shall ever meet again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo smiles up at her.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: I doubt it not;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet's face darkens.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O God, I have an ill-divining soul. Methinks I see thee, now thou art so low, As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo scrambles back up to the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Trust me, love, all these woes shall serve For sweet discourses in our times to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Juliet's bedroom comes the brittle sound of Gloria Capulet's voice.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Ho daughter! Are you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet spins around. Gloria has parted the curtains and i staring directly at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Well, well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: Romeo sheltered just below the lip of the balcony

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOW: His hand, as it slowly reaches up and touches Juliet's fingers hidden behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria returns to the room. Juliet steals a glance toward Romeo as he silently mouths:

dialogues.speaker: ROMEO
dialogues.text: Adieu, adieu!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Romeo's face disappears into the shadows Juliet whispe a little prayer to herself.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O Fortune, Fortune! Be fickle, Fortune, Fo then I hope thou wilt not keep him long But send him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet is trying not to cry as she goes in to her mother. Gloria turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Thou hast a careful father, child: One who, to put thee from thy heaviness, Hath sorted out a sudden day of joy That thou expects not nor I looked not for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet plays along.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Madam, in happy time. What day is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Marry, my child, early next Thursday

dialogues.speaker: MORN
dialogues.text: The gallant, young, and noble gentleman, Sir Paris, at Saint Peter's Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet. She can barely speak.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Now by Saint Peter's Church, and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear passes across Gloria's face.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Here comes your father. Tell him so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet - whisky glass in hand - ebulliently bursts into room.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: How now, wife? Have you delivered to her our decree?

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Ay, sir. But she will none, she gives you thanks. I would the fool were married to her grave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet - a dangerous calm.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: How? Will she none? Is she not proud? Doth she not count her blest, Unworthy as she is, that we have

dialogues.speaker: WROUGHT
dialogues.text: So worthy a gentleman to be her bride?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Not proud you have, but thankful that you have. Proud can I never be of what I hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE: Capulet considers his daughter, then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAM! He hurls his glass against the wall, shattering it into a thousand pieces.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Thank me no thankings, nor proud me no prouds, But fettle your fine joints 'gainst Thursday next ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet advances. Juliet, terrified, retreats into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Hear me with patience but to speak a word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse appears as Capulet picks his daughter up and shakes her like a rag doll.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Speak not, reply not, do not answer me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws her to the floor. His fist thuds as it slams in her face.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: (SCREAMING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fie, fie! What are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria tries to restrain Capulet. He back-hands her, sending her flying against the wall - bellowing insanely, advances on his cowering daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Hang thee, young baggage! Disobedient wretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse throws herself between Capulet and Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: God in heaven bless her! You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furious, Capulet shunts her aside.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET
dialogues.text: Peace, you mumbling fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet yanks his daughter's face close to his.

dialogues.speaker: CAPULET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I tell thee what - get thee to church a Thursday Or never after look me in the face. And you be mine, I'll give you to my friend. And you be not, hang, beg, starve, die in the streets, Trust to it. Bethink you. I'll not be forsworn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capulet storms off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet. She huddles, shaking at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O sweet my mother, cast me not away! Delay this marriage for a month, a week. Or if you do not, make the bridal

dialogues.speaker: BED
dialogues.text: In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trickle of blood issues from Gloria's cut lip. She chec her appearance in the hall mirror.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: Talk not to me, for I'll not speak a word. Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria leaves.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: O God! - O Nurse, how shall this be prevented?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What sayest thou? Hast thou not a word of joy? Some comfort, Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse goes to Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Faith, here it is. I think it best you married with this Paris. O, he's a lovely gentleman! I think you are happy in this second match, For it excels your first; or if it did not, Your first is dead - or 'twere as good he were As living here and you no use of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet is very still.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Speakest thou from thy heart?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: And from my soul too. Else beshrew them both.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (UNSURE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet is matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Well, thou hast comforted me marvellous much. Go in; and tell my lady I am gone, Having displeased my father, to Friar Laurence, To make confession and to be absolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old woman nods. She strokes Juliet's hair.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: This is wisely done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet does not look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disturbing choral chant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight pierces stained glass - the chant a sinister underscoring. We hear Dave Paris' voice:

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O/S)
dialogues.text: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt's death...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE DOWN: Father Laurence and Dave Paris stand at the front of the church.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: ...Now, sir, her father counts it

dialogues.speaker: DANGEROUS
dialogues.text: That she doth give her sorrow so much sway, And in his wisdom hastes our

dialogues.speaker: MARRIAGE
dialogues.text: To stop the inundation of her tears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence turns. Juliet stands framed in the white glare of the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Happily met, my lady and my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet's hand concealed beneath her coat - we c just see the handle of a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet advances slowly, an icy calm:

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That 'may be', must be, love, on Thursday next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet stares past Dave.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: What must be, shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence, a forced cheerfulness.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: That's a certain text.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Come you to make confession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Are you at leisure, holy father, now? Or shall I come to you at evening mass?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now. (to Dave) We must entreat the time alone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: God shield I should disturb devotion! - Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave bends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Juliet; she stares stonily ahead as Dave kisses her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Till then, adieu, and keep this holy kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK WITH: Juliet; she runs for the sacristy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet, shaking with sobs takes refuge in the shadows of small room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: O Juliet, I already know thy grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: Tell me not, Father, that thou hearest of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: It strains me past the compass of my wits.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (DESPERATELY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If in thy wisdom thou canst give no

dialogues.speaker: HELP
dialogues.text: Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this I'll help it presently!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the gun, pointing it towards herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrified, Father Laurence moves to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet, panicked, levels the gun at him.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Hold daughter!

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (through tears) Be not so long to speak. I lone to die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Laurence holds out a soothing hand.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE
dialogues.text: I do spy a kind of hope, Which craves as desperate an

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTION
dialogues.text: As that is desperate which we would prevent. If, rather than marry Paris, Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself, Then it is likely thou wilt

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKE
dialogues.text: A thing like death...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the distended chords of Faur's Requiem.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: to chide away this shame...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It continues throughout as;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire screen fills with a glinting tear drop of blue liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reflected in the fluid's convex surface, the face of Fath Laurence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The face disappears as the tear drop falls and splashes i a clear water solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a comet in slow motion, the drop stains the water a cobalt hue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: The blue liquid fills a tiny glass vial held b Father Laurence.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: No warmth, no breath shall testify thou livest. Each part, deprived of supple government, Shall stiff and stark and cold appear, like death. Now when the bridegroom in the

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Comes to rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou, dead. Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie. In the meantime, against thou shalt awake, Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift, And hither shall he come. And that very Night shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest cautiously hands Juliet the vial.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER LAURENCE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Take thou this vial, being then in bed, And this distilling liquor drink thou off. I'll send my letters to thy lord with speed to Mantua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Father Laurence speaks, the screen fills with an expre envelope addressed "Romeo - Mantua." The envelope pulls a from the camera and falls into a canvas bag brimming with hundreds of like envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACK: With the canvas bag. It continues its journey into the back of an express delivery van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy double doors slam shut, filling the screen with the slogan 'Speed Express.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burning red sun is setting over an endless vista of rag wasteland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRANE DOWN: A weathered sign reads - Mantua: Behind it a vast colony of permanent trailer homes stretches into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rap, rap, rap of knocking echoes through the park...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: The source of the knocking. An express delivery man, envelope in hand, raps vigorously on the door of an unremarkable trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOPOGRAPHICAL SHOT: Romeo lies flat on a single bed in th crampled trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rap, rap, rap is very loud now. We move toward Romeo and realise he cannot hear the knocking because he has Walkman headphones on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unsuccessful, the delivery man is filling out a "WE CALLE card. He pushes it under the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heraldic 'Wedding Chimes' by JS Bach. Juliet stands resplendent in a radiant bridal gown. The image floats ethereally in a towering slab of mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL OUT: From the mirror. The wedding dress is in fact being held in front of Juliet by two members of the house staff. Juliet is dressed in her night gown. The Nurse suggests various pairs of shoes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (DISINTERESTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay, these attires are best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fuss dispensed with, the staff leave.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: But, gentle Nurse, I pray thee leave me to myself tonight.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Why Bride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet navigates the Nurse toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (almost in tears) To move the heavens to smile upon my state, Which, well thou knowest, is cross and full of sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet holds the Nurse in a pleading stare. She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone now, Juliet hurries to her bedside drawer. She cautiously removes a rolled piece of cloth from which she produces the glass vial.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (WHISPERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if this mixture do not work at all? Shall I be married then tomorrow morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cautiously begins to unscrew the tiny black lid. Suddenly, a knock at her door. Palming the vial, Juliet swings around to meet the arrival of her mother. Gloria probes her daughter's uneasiness.

dialogues.speaker: GLORIA
dialogues.text: What, are you busy, ho? Need you my help?

dialogues.speaker: JULIET
dialogues.text: (makes light of it) No, madam. We have culled such

dialogues.speaker: NECESSARIES
dialogues.text: As are behoveful for our state tomorrow. So please you, let me now be left alone, And let the Nurse this night sit up with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juliet begins to pull down the covers on her bed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIET, (CONT.)
